newsitem.title: USA: Blue-chips edge lower, dollar rises.
newsitem.headline: Blue-chips edge lower, dollar rises.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks edged lower Monday, the dollar rose again against the Japanese yen and other currencies, and bonds ended little changed.
Oil prices rose. Gold edged higher.
In the stock market, investors took a defensive stance in the next-to-last session of another solid year on Wall Street.

The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 11.54 points at 6,549.37 after spending much of the session higher. A late burst of computer-driven sell programmes erased the rally, thwarting the Dow's run at a second straight record.
The index of 30 blue-chip issues rose 14.23 points to a record 6,560.91 on Friday.

"Though it's hard to pick out a message from a day like today, it certainly seems the market has a defensive lean to it," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany. "It reflects a deepening concern that it's going to be tough to make money in the market next year."
The Dow actually spent most of the session modestly higher, boosted by strong performances from oil companies Chevron, Texaco and Exxon.
But a pair of late sell programmes slashed more than 42 points off the Dow in the last 35 minutes of trading, according to Birinyi Associates, a firm that tracks programme trading.
While the Dow ended lower, 1,402 stocks rose and 1,065 fell in the broader market on light New York Stock Exchange volume of 339 million shares.
Many investors took vacation this week because of the New Year's holiday on Wednesday.
At Monday's close with one session left in 1996, the Dow's gain for 1996 stood at a very strong 28 percent, especially since the blue-chip index rose 33.5 percent in 1995.
In currency markets, the dollar rose against the yen amid a sudden lack of public pressure from Japanese officials to try to hold up the value of the Japanese currency.
In late U.S. trading, the dollar settled at 116.15 yen, up from 115.30 yen on Friday. The dollar rose slightly to 1.5550 German marks from 1.5545 marks.
The yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury was steady at 6.54 percent.
Crude oil for February delivery rose 15 cents to $25.37 a barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
February gold added 10 cents to close at $371.20 an ounce at New York's Commodity Exchange.
Overseas, London's FTSE 100 index rose 24.7 points to a record 4,115.7, and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 average fell 7.69 points to 19,361.35.
